extension.valueCode: Logical Models that have been modified for R4 are still draft while real-world experience is collected

name: TestCases
title: Test Cases
description: A standard format for test cases used throughout the FHIR ecosystem

element.short: Test Suite - set of tests executed by a runner
element.definition: A set of tests that are executed by some runner to test the functionality of a tool in the FHIR ecosystem

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Canonical identifier for these tests, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify test tests.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic

element.short: Business version of the test set (semver)
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of these tests. Version must use SemVer

element.short: Name for these tests
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the tests. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.

element.short: General Description of these tests
element.definition: General description of these teats.

element.short: The scope - what these test cases are testing
element.definition: The scope indicates what kind of systems these test cases are intended to test

element.short: A reference to what is being tested
element.definition: A reference to what is being tested

element.short: Description of what the scope is exists / what is being tested
element.definition: Description of what the scope is does / what is being tested

element.short: Test cases that must be passed before these test cases are meaningful to execute
element.definition: Another set of test cases that must be passed before these test cases are meaningful to execute. These test cases prove functionality that these tests require to execute

element.short: The Test Cases
element.definition: The test cases.

element.short: Description of what the dependency exists / why it was defined
element.definition: Description of what this mode does / why it was defined. This should explain to a tester why the

element.short: URL Documentation for a runner that executes these tests
element.definition: URL of documentation that explains how a runner would read these tests, and use them to actually test out a tool.

element.short: A mode that can be passed to runner - affects test content
element.definition: A mode that can be passed to a runner running these these tests, that affects test content and influences how the tests are executed or evaulated (or even if they run)

element.short: The code that identifies the mode
element.definition: The code by which the mode is identified when passed to runner

element.short: Description of what this mode exists / why it was defined
element.definition: Description of what this mode does / why it was defined. This should explain to a tester when they should use the mode

element.short: Parameter passed to the runner
element.definition: A parameter passed to the runner when executing tests. Which parameters are valid, and how exactly the parameter is used are used depends on the definition of the runner

element.short: Name of parameter
element.definition: Name of parameter

element.short: Value of this parameter
element.definition: The value of the parameter. If the value is an Expression, the definition of the runner describes what kind of expressions are allowed and the features/capabilities that they can make use of

element.short: A mode that must be true for this parameter to be used
element.definition: If this mode is not passed to the runner, then this parameter will not be used
element.meaningWhenMissing: If no modes are listed, the parameter is always used, unless there is a parameter with the same name that is selected by mode

element.short: A suite of tests that share a common set up
element.definition: A suite of tests that all share a common set up, and can be executed as a group

element.short: The name of this suite - unique in the TestCases resource
element.definition: The name by which this suite is known by in the test system. The name must be unique in the amongst the suites

element.short: Description of what this suite does / why it was defined
element.definition: Description of what this suite does / why it was defined. This should explain to a tester what they should know when deciding which tests to run

element.short: mode required to run this suite
element.definition: If this mode is not passed to the runner, then this suite will not be run
element.meaningWhenMissing: If no modes are listed, the suite is always executed

element.short: Resources used in the tests in this suite
element.definition: The resources used in the tests in this suite. How exactly they are used depends on the definition of the runner

constraint.human: Either a file, or a resource, but not both

element.short: A name for this resource (per runner definition)
element.definition: A name that identifies this resource. The runner definition defines whether there must be a name, and what names there are

element.short: A file containing a resource used in the tests
element.definition: A file containing a resource used in the tests
element.comment: Filename is relative to the folder/directory containing this TestCases

element.short: An inline resource used in the tests
element.definition: An inline resource used in the tests. How exactly it is used depends on the definition of the runner.

element.short: A mode that must be true for this resource to be used
element.definition: If this mode is not passed to the runner, then this resource will not be used
element.meaningWhenMissing: If no modes are listed, the resource is always used, unless there is another entry with the same name that is selected by mode

element.short: Parameter passed to the runner
element.definition: A parameter passed to the runner when executing tests. Which parameters are valid, and how exactly the parameter is used are used depends on the definition of the runner

element.short: A test in the test suite
element.definition: An actual test in the test suite

element.short: The name of this test - unique in the suite
element.definition: The name by which this test is known by in the test system. The name must be unique in the suite

element.short: Description of what this test does / why it was defined
element.definition: Description of what this test does / why it was defined. This should explain to a tester what they should know when looking at failing test results

element.short: Operation that is executed during this test (per definition of runner)
element.definition: A code that identifies the operation executed for this test. One of the codes defined in the definition of the runner

element.short: mode required to run this test
element.definition: If this mode is not passed to the runner, then this test will not be run
element.meaningWhenMissing: If no modes are listed, the test is always executed

element.short: Resources used when executing this test (per runner definition)
element.definition: The resources used when executing this test. How exactly they are used depends on the definition of the runner.

element.short: Resources expected as output from this test (per runner definition, often Matchetypes)
element.definition: Resources expected as output from this test. Often, but not always, these resources are Matchetype resources. How exactly it is used depends on the definition of the runner. How exactly it is used depends on the definition of the runner, but the expectation is that these are the expected output, to which the actual output is compared

element.short: Assertions that can be executed against the output of the tests
element.definition: One or more assertions that can be executed against the output of the tests. These may be used with matchetypes to make rules about content the matchetypes leave open

element.short: Which output the assertion is tested on (by name, if there is more than one)
element.definition: Resources expected as output from this test. Often, but not always, these resources are Matchetype resources

element.short: Error | Warning | Information; only errors are considered to cause a test to fail
element.definition: Resources expected as output from this test. Often, but not always, these resources are Matchetype resources. How exactly it is used depends on the definition of the runner

element.short: Technical Expression of the assertion
element.definition: Resources expected as output from this test. Often, but not always, these resources are Matchetype resources. How exactly it is used depends on the definition of the runner

element.short: Human readable description of the assertion
element.definition: A human readable description of the assertion.

element.short: A mode that must be true for this assertion to apply
element.definition: If this mode is not passed to the runner, then this assertion will not be used
element.meaningWhenMissing: If no modes are listed, the assertion is always used, unless there is another assertion with the same name that is selected by mode

element.short: A nested suite of tests
element.definition: A nested set of tests

element.short: A nested set of test cases
element.definition: A nested set of test cases. Typically, the runner must be the same in the nested test cases

element.short: Test Suite - set of tests executed by a runner
element.definition: A set of tests that are executed by some runner to test the functionality of a tool in the FHIR ecosystem
